metadata.case_name: Writ Petition No. 1607 of 1973 (Petitioner v. State of West Bengal)

facts.text: Petitioner moved Court under Art. 32 for writ of habeas corpus, being under detention by order of District Magistrate, Burdwan, under sub-s.(1) read with sub-s.(2) of S.3 of Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971.
Various grounds, similar to those considered in Bhut Nath Mete v. State of West Bengal, urged by petitioner.

In affidavit-in-opposition filed on behalf of respondent: 'it appears from the records that the detenue petitioner is a man of desperate habits and dangerous character and also prone to committing theft of underground telecommunication cable.'
This statement relied upon by State as additional ground in support of detention, apart from theft of cables recited in detention order and counter affidavit.
Additional circumstance placed before State Government and Advisory Board, and before District Magistrate when passing detention order.
Counsel for respondent candidly admitted the above.
Authorities influenced by police report that petitioner was man of desperate habits and dangerous character and prone to committing theft of underground cables.

legal_issues.text: Whether the detention order is valid given reliance on vague description of 'desperate habits and dangerous character' and non-communication of the police dossier to the petitioner for representation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Various grounds similar to those considered in Bhut Nath Mete v. State of West Bengal urged.

respondent_arguments.text: Reliance on affidavit statement that petitioner is man of desperate habits, dangerous character, prone to theft of cables as additional ground supporting detention.

court_reasoning.text: Desperate habits and dangerous character regarded as vague; vice of vagueness may not matter for authorities' satisfaction but every desperate or dangerous man cannot be detained under S.3 of MISA.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Desperate habits and dangerous character' is vague.

court_reasoning.text: Vital yet injurious dossier about petitioner not communicated to him and no opportunity afforded for making representation contra.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Violation of Art. 22(5) of Constitution and S.3(3) of the Act.

court_reasoning.text: Conclusions similar to those in Bhut Nath Mete v. State of West Bengal.

holdings.text: Detention order quashed due to vagueness of grounds and violation of constitutional and statutory right to representation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhut Nath Mete v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.citation: Writ Petition No. 1456 of 1973, judgment delivered on February 8, 1974
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar grounds urged and similar conclusions reached.

statutes_cited.name: Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971
statutes_cited.relevance: Detention under S.3(1) r/w S.3(2); violation of S.3(3) for non-communication of grounds.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition under Art.32; violation of Art.22(5) right to representation.

outcome.summary: Court quashes the detention order passed by District Magistrate, Burdwan under MISA and directs release of the petitioner due to vagueness of the grounds relied upon and failure to communicate the police dossier for representation, violating Art.22(5) and S.3(3).
outcome.relief_granted: Quashing of detention order and direction for release.

key_quotes.text: We do not regard desperate habits and dangerous Character as anything but vague.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Identifies vagueness as key defect in detention grounds.

key_quotes.text: this vital yet injurious dossier about the petitioner has not been communicated to him and opportunity afforded for making a proper representation contra. Therefore there is violation both of art. 22(5) of the Constitution and of s.3(3) of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States the constitutional and statutory violations leading to quashing.
